docs.snippet: The BBC’s historical costume and wigs department has been forced to shut down after a deal to sell the department to a rival props company collapsed, The Times of London reported. The failure of the sale, part of a cost-saving drive, has created...
docs.lead_paragraph: The BBC’s historical costume and wigs department has been forced to shut down after a deal to sell the department to a rival props company collapsed, The Times of London reported. The failure of the sale, part of a cost-saving drive, has created a crisis for period-drama productions. The BBC’s costume vault houses about one million outfits and 12,000 hairpieces. But BBC Resources, as the operation is called, has announced that it is shutting down. The costumes and wigs will be moved from London to Oxford and held in storage until their future becomes clear. The shutdown comes after the BBC announced a series of period pieces, including productions of “Tess of the D’Urbervilles” and “Little Dorrit.” A permanent closing would also hit film production. Sofia Coppola’s 2006 film “Marie Antoinette,” which won the Oscar for costume design, used 400 items rented from the department.

docs.snippet: The ceremony is full-speed ahead, and the A-List is heading to town....
docs.lead_paragraph: The men behind the curtain met with the press yesterday and it appears that Oz is under rapid construction. Michael Cieply reports that Sid Ganis, president of the Academy, and Gil Cates, the producer of this year's show, are wiping the flop sweat out of their eyes after months of wondering whether they were going to have to come up with a work-around and are now full steam ahead with Plan A. And there will be no shortage of A-Listers.
docs.abstract: The ceremony is full-speed ahead, and the A-List is heading to town.

docs.snippet: Finally, after all the seriousness, it's O.K. for Oscar ninnies to celebrate the silly season....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger has to admit that there seems to be a bit of an energy crisis around Oscar town. At this time in the previous seasons, there would be missiles flying back and forth from various camps and people would be genuinely frantic about who was going to win what.
docs.abstract: Finally, after all the seriousness, it's O.K. for Oscar ninnies to celebrate the silly season.

docs.snippet: Lynn Hirschberg, T Magazine's editor at large, has a remarkable nose for Oscar nods. She plays a featured role in selecting the actors and actresses who will be photographed for the covers of T's fashion issues, then interviews them for the magazi...
docs.lead_paragraph: Lynn Hirschberg, T Magazine's editor at large, has a remarkable nose for Oscar nods. She plays a featured role in selecting the actors and actresses who will be photographed for the covers of T's fashion issues, then interviews them for the magazine and for T's "Screentest" films. One of her criteria: Is their work in the coming season Oscar worthy? As the 10 covers shown on the new home page of our mothersite, nytimes.com/tmagazine, show, she's frequently right. Among the T talent hoping for gold at the Hollywood ceremony on Sunday Feb. 24 are Marion Cotillard and Tilda Swinton. Good luck, ladies.
